question:
Can an acute infiltrate be seen on the chest X-ray? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]
<image>
variation_1:
Is there evidence of an acute alveolar infiltrate on the chest radiograph? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]
<image>
variation_2:
Does the chest X-ray show a patchy consolidation consistent with an acute pneumonic process? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]
<image>
variation_3:
Can a fluid-filled lobe be identified on the chest film, suggestive of an acute alveolitis? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]
<image>
variation_4:
Is there radiographic evidence of an air-space consolidation consistent with a bacterial pneumonia? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]

<image>
variation_6:
Does the radiograph reveal a patchy, homogeneous opacity consistent with an acute pulmonary infiltrate? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]
<image>
variation_7:
Can a focal area of increased opacification be seen on the chest film, suggesting an acute lung infection? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]

variation_8:
Is the chest X-ray consistent with a diagnosis of an acute alveolar filling process? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]
